repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Transport Sector Reform and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Transport Sector Reform and
            Rehabilitation Project for Madagascar had the following
            ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: Project
            development objectives need to be aligned with project
            content. An effective monitoring and evaluation system
            should be priority of the borrower and the Bank.
            Borrower's effective commitment is essential to achieve
            sector reforms. Borrower's ownership of policy is
            necessary to ensure operations efficiency and
            sustainability. Clear criteria of staff performance and
            qualification should lead to decision on their selection and
            replacement, for a result-driven action. Bank's
            decentralization policy facilitates continuous dialogue and
            closer follow-up of the project's implementation.
            Borrower's commitment to more transparency improves
            sector's governance. Implementation arrangements need
            to be adjusted as necessary. The Bank should be more
            realistic when expecting results, especially for such
            projects requiring thorough institutional changes and
            vulnerable to staff rotation and change of decision makers.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Transport Sector Reform and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Transport Sector Reform and
            Rehabilitation Project will strengthen transport sector
            policy, and management, supporting the liberalization of
            transport services, and, will reactivate trade, including
            the promotion of public/private partnerships of primary
            transport facilities. The components call for: 1) regulatory
            reform, and private sector development, to develop a
            domestic private sector, active in the transport sector.
            Sub-sectors include regulatory framework for civil aviation;
            port sub-sector reform; commercialization, and liquidation
            of the Ministry of Public Works' (MOPW) construction
            units; development of a domestic road transport, and
            construction industries; and, promote trade, and transport
            facilitation; 2) restructuring of MOPW, which will include
            consulting services, technical assistance, and training, to
            assist with the establishment of transitional arrangements
            among the decentralized units. A social mitigation program
            will be financed, to address redundancy quantities,
            statutory entitlements, and staff reinsertion into the labor
            market; 3) environmental protection to monitor the sector
            environmental performance, and, present a national
            catastrophe prevention, and mitigation program. In addition,
            both emergency works, and studies will be financed to
            support coastal protection activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Transport Restructuring &
            Investment Program Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental assessment contains
            two volumes, the first focuses primarily on the hulk removal
            of a mineral cargo ship from the Tolagnaro Bay, followed by
            the rehabilitation of two other ports, and river control
            management; and, the second, examines the impact as a result
            of roads construction. Volume I addresses pollution risks
            associated to the continuous manganese, and hydrocarbon
            spillage from the hulk's cargo, whose toxic products
            endangers local ecosystems. The removal works will further
            increase serious air, and water pollution in the bay, in
            addition to the economic adversity, resulting from higher
            transportation costs due to shipping de-tours, and illicit
            trafficking. Mitigation measures recommend: 1)
            implementation of ecological, and biological studies to
            identify negative pollution impacts; 2) performance of
            toxicity tests on fisheries products; 3) regulation of
            fishing activities, and adequate dredging to prevent land
            degradation, flora and fauna disturbances, and, sanitary
            measures should be enforced. Volume II identifies adverse
            effects during, and after road construction, such as
            potential water, air, and noise pollution, and, ecological
            damage. Measures to mitigate adverse effects call for: 1)
            judicious practices on site selection; 2) noise abatement
            measures, including the construction of sound barriers; 3)
            enforcement of traffic safety measures; and, 4) public
            awareness development.
